catalog.title: Biomed Informatics Apps
catalog.description: This is a required introductory course in the first year of the master's degree in Biomedical Informatics and it is also open to students in other graduate degree programs who have completed BMI 501. It provides an overview of health care informatics application domains that build on or complement electronic health record systems as well as an introductory overview of the information management challenges of the U.S. and major international health care, public health and biomedical research systems. The class will include field-trip visits to local health care and other organizations to see these informatics applications in use, and to learn from the systems development and maintenance staff as well as end-users in these settings.
catalog.subject: Biomedical Informatics
catalog.long_title: Biomedical Informatics Application Domains: U.S. & International

catalog.title: Sociotechnical Informatics
catalog.description: The course reviews the interdisciplinary frameworks, and design concepts, used in human factors engineering and ergonomics for biomedical information systems, such as, organizational/social and environmental challenges of human-computer interactions and information technology on clinical and research user performance.
catalog.subject: Biomedical Informatics

catalog.title: BMS Research Methods
catalog.description: This course provides an introduction to research design and methods in biomedical informatics and aims to enhance the students' quantitative and qualitative research skills. The course will be surveying the formulation of research questions, the development of testable hypotheses, the selection and application of appropriate research designs and methods, data collection and analysis methods. These skills can be applied in subsequent courses and research projects. A key element is the evaluation of published research papers. The course consists of six themes: the fundamentals of scientific research; qualitative research methods including statistics; clinical epidemiology, population studies and big data; theoretically informed qualitative research; integration of research methods in biomedical informatics; research ethics, including informed consent, and role of IRBs. The course will encompass lectures and practicums.
catalog.subject: Biomedical Informatics

catalog.title: Clin Informatics & Decsn Spt
catalog.description: Building on BMI 501 as a prerequisite, this course provides an in-depth exploration of the purpose, scope, technical structures & uses of electronic health records (EHR) and other clinical health care information systems. Then, building on a review of current research on human cognition & decision making, the course critically reviews the purposes, scope, technical structures and ethical uses of computer-based decision support systems in clinical health care and consumer health settings.
catalog.subject: Biomedical Informatics

notes.note: Classes will be held at 77 Goodell St (UB Downtown Gateway Bldg), Room 506.  Upper undergraduate level or graduate level math, computing science, chemistry, physics, biology and some Unix experience

catalog.title: Advanced Bioinformatics
catalog.description: This course provides Master's students with experience with advanced methods, systems, tools and databases available for the multiscale modelling, analysis, and interpretation of the increasingly voluminous molecular, genomic, and proteomic data. The focus is on advanced exercises that make use of these biological big data for research in molecular and systems biology, genetics, genomics, and proteomics as well as for translating and integration with clinical health care data to help predict and prevent disease. Students will be provided a strong foundation in structural and translational bioinformatics by using advanced homology detection methods, macromolecular structure modelling, whole interactome modelling, and integrative tools to perform sophisticated analyses of genomic, epigenetic, gene expression and proteomic data.
catalog.subject: Biomedical Informatics
catalog.long_title: Advanced Bioinformatics and Translational Research Informatics

catalog.title: Advanced Bioinformatics

catalog.subject: Biomedical Informatics
catalog.long_title: Advanced Bioinformatics and Translational Research Informatics

catalog.title: Public Health Informatics
catalog.description: BMI 506 will provide training in the concepts, and methods of biomedical informatics and health/clinical information technology as it applies to the discipline of public health. The intended audience is current and future practitioners in the broad domain of public health as well as clinicians and other biomedical scientists who wish to develop expertise in the field.
catalog.subject: Biomedical Informatics
catalog.long_title: Clinical Population Research and Public Health Informatics

courses.title: BMI J Club Sem Res Pract

catalog.title: BMI J Club Sem Res Pract
catalog.description: This Fall Semester companion course to BMI 501 provides an introduction to the biomedical informatics journal and monograph literature, databases and information management tools. Students will also review the methods for critically reading, summarizing and presenting a journal article for discussion and must attend three faculty or visiting researcher seminar presentations. Finally, each student will spend three weeks with a member of the BMI faculty, learning about and helping with some aspect of their research. At the end of the semester, each student will give a brief presentation reporting on this research practicum experience.
catalog.subject: Biomedical Informatics
catalog.long_title: BMI Journal Club, Seminars and Research Practicum

catalog.title: Advanced Bioinformatics
catalog.description: This course provides students with hands on experience with advanced methods, systems, tools and databases available for the multiscale modelling, analysis, and interpretation of the increasingly voluminous molecular, genomic, and proteomic data. The focus is on advanced exercises that make use of these biological big data for research in molecular and systems biology, genetics, genomics, and proteomics as well as for translating and integration with clinical health care data to help predict and prevent disease. Students will be provided a strong foundation in structural and translational bioinformatics by using advanced homology detection methods, macromolecular structure modelling, whole interactome modelling, and integrative tools to perform sophisticated analyses of genomic, epigenetic, gene expression and proteomic data.
catalog.subject: Biomedical Informatics
catalog.long_title: Advanced Topics in Bioinformatics and Translational Research Informatics

notes.note: Class will be held in Room 506, 77 Goodell Street (UB Downtown Gateway Bldg)

catalog.title: Referent Tracking
catalog.description: Building further on previous courses in biomedical ontology, databases and research methods, this course provides an in-depth exploration of the purpose, scope, technical structures & uses of Referent Tracking as a methodology to design information systems that are maximally self-explanatory and explicit in terms of the data they manage and self-aware in terms of their interactions with other systems and users thereof. The course includes theoretical lectures, group discussions and guided exercises, the latter aimed to help integrate all aspects of Referent Tracking into prototype applications useful for the students' PhD thesis work.
catalog.subject: Biomedical Informatics
catalog.long_title: Principles of Referent Tracking in Biomedical Informatics

catalog.title: Mentored Research Rotation
catalog.description: This course, repeated for the first four semesters of the Ph.D. program, provides each student with experience working in the research labs of three to four different members of the BMI faculty to get a broader perspective on the research challenges of the field and to help the student choose one of the five BMI Department divisions as well as the specific research questions for his or her dissertation research. The student's faculty research mentors and research lab rotations will be chosen in consultation with each student's faculty advisor, based on how the student's interests and research goals complement those of the Department's faculty.
catalog.subject: Biomedical Informatics

catalog.title: BMI Dissertation Writing
catalog.description: This required 4 credit hour course, repeated during the last two semesters at the end of the BMI Ph.D. program, provides time for the candidate to complete his or her dissertation research with the writing of a publishable dissertation thesis and the preparation of a formal presentation and defense of the research results.

catalog.title: BMI Adv Mentored Res Proj
catalog.description: Students will participate in a research project defined by the mentor. At a minimum the project will include laboratory work to gain good familiarity with the methods and challenges of this area of research, additional readings in journals and other literature sources, a written report summarizing the findings from the project, and an oral presentation for interested faculty and students based on the report.
catalog.subject: Biomedical Informatics

catalog.title: Research
catalog.description: This is work designed to do mentored project related work with defined endpoints and grades associated with those endpoints. In our Masters program this would be a practicum which students have as a requirement for graduation. In our PhD program it is one step prior to independent research with their mentor which gives all students exposure to good general research methods and skills. Students will have a defined project and should have a manuscript written as their final exam.
catalog.subject: Biomedical Informatics
